quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: In our conversation, we get into all kinds of juicy advice, including why companies don't have to be run well to win, why you don't need a career plan, the two habits she credits most for helping her succeed throughout her career, what she learned from Jeff Bezos and Stewart Butterfield and Marc Benioff, how to build stronger cross-functional relationships and a bunch of advice on AI including how it will likely change your jobs, examples of how she and her colleagues are already using AI to be more productive in their work and what she's learned about building AI-based products that are non-deterministic and can be very unpredictable.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A dense preview of the episode’s most actionable and contrarian themes, including career strategy, cross-functional leadership, and practical AI/product lessons.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: This episode is for anyone looking to level up as a leader and get a better sense of how AI will change your job.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Sets the practical intent of the conversation: leadership growth plus concrete implications of AI on day-to-day work.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Tamar was chief product officer at Slack for four years where she led product design and research as the company scaled 10Xed their revenue, went through IPO and then got bought by Salesforce.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A specific scaling data point that anchors her credibility and signals experience operating through hypergrowth and major company transitions.

quotes.topic_title: Career success habits: excel and understand people
quotes.text: One of the things that I think is overlooked is do a really good job at whatever your job is at that point.
quotes.speaker: Tamar Yehoshua
quotes.context: Highlights a foundational but often neglected career accelerant: excelling in the role you already have.

quotes.topic_title: Career success habits: excel and understand people
quotes.text: People have a tendency ... Especially product managers are very ambitious and they want to get to the next level and they're always eyeing the next job, but you're not going to get the next job unless you do really well at the job that you're in.
quotes.speaker: Tamar Yehoshua
quotes.context: Counters the common focus on leveling up by emphasizing performance in the current role as the prerequisite for advancement.

quotes.topic_title: Career success habits: excel and understand people
quotes.text: Knock it out of the park. However simple, however easy it may be to you, do a great job.
quotes.speaker: Tamar Yehoshua
quotes.context: A memorable standard for execution: treat even “easy” work as an opportunity to demonstrate excellence.

quotes.topic_title: Career success habits: excel and understand people
quotes.text: And in tech jobs, there's table stakes.
quotes.speaker: Tamar Yehoshua
quotes.context: Introduces a useful mental model—separating baseline expectations from differentiators in career growth.

quotes.topic_title: Career success habits: excel and understand people
quotes.text: There's table stakes of you need to be technical, you need to know the latest technology, you need to understand your product, the product you're working on. No matter what your role is. You have to understand it deeply. You need to understand metrics.
quotes.speaker: Tamar Yehoshua
quotes.context: Defines concrete “table stakes” competencies practitioners can self-assess and build to avoid being filtered out.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: So after you've done a great job at everything and you understand the core skills that you need, another thing you really need to know is understanding people and motivations.
quotes.speaker: Tamar Yehoshua
quotes.context: Highlights a key leadership transition: moving from execution and core skills to mastering human motivation.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: And when you're building products, you have to understand why does somebody want to use your product? What problem are they solving? Why do they want to click on that button?
quotes.speaker: Tamar Yehoshua
quotes.context: Provides a practical user-motivation checklist for product decisions and UX prioritization.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: What's going to make them feel good when they click on it? What's going to give them delight and what's also going to make them feel bad and frustrated and what do they not want to do?
quotes.speaker: Tamar Yehoshua
quotes.context: Encourages designing for both positive and negative emotional outcomes to reduce friction and increase delight.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: So just like why does somebody want to click on a button, why does somebody want to join your team? Why do they want to work hard? What are they trying to accomplish? What's the goal for their career?
quotes.speaker: Tamar Yehoshua
quotes.context: Extends the same motivation lens from product users to team members, offering a unified model for product and people leadership.

quotes.topic_title: Learning to read the room and motivations
quotes.text: another thing you really need to know is understanding people and motivations.
quotes.speaker: Tamar Yehoshua
quotes.context: Highlights the key leadership transition skill beyond execution: developing a deep grasp of human motivations.

quotes.topic_title: Learning to read the room and motivations
quotes.text: when you're building products, you have to understand why does somebody want to use your product? What problem are they solving? Why do they want to click on that button? What's going to make them feel good when they click on it? What's going to give them delight and what's also going to make them feel bad and frustrated and what do they not want to do?
quotes.speaker: Tamar Yehoshua
quotes.context: Provides a practical motivation-led checklist for product design decisions focused on user intent and emotional outcomes.

quotes.topic_title: Learning to read the room and motivations
quotes.text: So just like why does somebody want to click on a button, why does somebody want to join your team? Why do they want to work hard? What are they trying to accomplish? What's the goal for their career?
quotes.speaker: Tamar Yehoshua
quotes.context: Connects product motivation thinking directly to team leadership by applying the same “why” analysis to people management.

quotes.topic_title: Learning to read the room and motivations
quotes.text: So you have to be able to read people, ask lots of questions to understand them.
quotes.speaker: Tamar Yehoshua
quotes.context: Actionable guidance for building intuition: observe closely and interrogate assumptions through questions.

quotes.topic_title: Learning to read the room and motivations
quotes.text: it taught me to see the whole room. To see how people react. Like Lenny, if you say something and somebody else is there, look at the other person. What's their face saying? You can understand so much if you're paying attention.
quotes.speaker: Tamar Yehoshua
quotes.context: A concrete observational method for reading group dynamics by watching non-speakers’ reactions, not just the person talking.

quotes.topic_title: Balancing metrics with intuition and perspective
quotes.text: One of the things that I caution product managers about is that you don't want to be too overly reliant on metrics and you want to also have an intuition.
quotes.speaker: Tamar Yehoshua
quotes.context: A contrarian reminder to balance quantitative metrics with qualitative product judgment when making decisions.

quotes.topic_title: Balancing metrics with intuition and perspective
quotes.text: How do you get good at it? Ask a lot of questions. Don't assume you know.
quotes.speaker: Tamar Yehoshua
quotes.context: Actionable guidance for building better customer intuition through deliberate curiosity and avoiding assumptions.

quotes.topic_title: Balancing metrics with intuition and perspective
quotes.text: Marc Benioff would always say, "Have a beginner's mind. Go in assuming that you know nothing and listen to your customers, listen to the people."
quotes.speaker: Tamar Yehoshua
quotes.context: A memorable mental model for customer discovery: approach users with humility to learn what actually matters.

quotes.topic_title: Balancing metrics with intuition and perspective
quotes.text: Well, no, you got to earn that right.
quotes.speaker: Tamar Yehoshua
quotes.context: A sharp principle for UI prioritization: features should earn prominence based on user value, not team attachment.

quotes.topic_title: Balancing metrics with intuition and perspective
quotes.text: So have perspective. Have perspective of what your users are actually trying to achieve.
quotes.speaker: Tamar Yehoshua
quotes.context: A practical lens for product decisions: prioritize the user’s goal over internal preferences or “pet features.”

quotes.topic_title: What “doing a great job” really means
quotes.text: Are you helping the business move forward?
quotes.speaker: Tamar Yehoshua
quotes.context: A simple litmus test that reframes performance from task completion to business impact.

quotes.topic_title: What “doing a great job” really means
quotes.text: So it's not about I achieve what I was asked to do, but did you build something that people actually used?
quotes.speaker: Tamar Yehoshua
quotes.context: Actionable guidance to measure success by real adoption and usefulness, not just meeting assigned goals.

quotes.topic_title: What “doing a great job” really means
quotes.text: I took a vacation, I came back and I said, "I don't think this team should exist."
quotes.speaker: Tamar Yehoshua
quotes.context: A counterintuitive career move illustrating prioritizing company outcomes over personal advancement.

quotes.topic_title: What “doing a great job” really means
quotes.text: It was my first management job and I wanted to be a manager.
quotes.speaker: Tamar Yehoshua
quotes.context: Highlights the tension between ambition and doing what’s right for the business.

quotes.topic_title: What “doing a great job” really means
quotes.text: If I were to put this into one word, it's impact. Drive impact.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A memorable summary that turns the segment into a clear operating principle for getting ahead.

quotes.topic_title: Companies can win while being poorly run
quotes.text: But what I've seen is when a company isn't well run like IT isn't working, marketing is broken, there are not enough people in HR, there's a lot of turnover. All of these things I've seen that they're not correlated to the company being successful.
quotes.speaker: Tamar Yehoshua
quotes.context: Contrarian observation that internal dysfunction often doesn’t predict whether the business will succeed, helping leaders prioritize what to fix first.

quotes.topic_title: Companies can win while being poorly run
quotes.text: Where there's high executive turnover. Where people get yelled at. There are lots of people fired. There's reorgs all the time. People I talk to are super unhappy, but the numbers are amazing. They're growing like crazy.
quotes.speaker: Tamar Yehoshua
quotes.context: Concrete example showing that even extreme organizational chaos can coexist with strong growth, challenging assumptions about “healthy company = winning company.”

quotes.topic_title: Companies can win while being poorly run
quotes.text: And the opposite sit is also true. I can think of one company I know really well, amazing, CEO, well run, well oiled machine, everything. Hired good executives and they flat lined.
quotes.speaker: Tamar Yehoshua
quotes.context: Counterexample that a well-run organization can still fail to grow, reinforcing that operational excellence isn’t sufficient for success.

quotes.topic_title: Companies can win while being poorly run
quotes.text: So what are the things that really matter? We always talk about product market fit. Nobody really knows what product market fit is. Everybody has a different explanation, but it means people want to use your product. That they're clamoring for it.
quotes.speaker: Tamar Yehoshua
quotes.context: A practical definition of product-market fit that teams can use to evaluate whether they’re building something users truly demand.

quotes.topic_title: Companies can win while being poorly run
quotes.text: You need to build a great product, but you also have to have distribution and you need to have a sales team that works. And you have to have enough money in the bank to get there.
quotes.speaker: Tamar Yehoshua
quotes.context: Actionable prioritization framework: product value isn’t enough without distribution, effective sales, and runway.

quotes.topic_title: Hypergrowth chaos: why it happens and limits
quotes.text: You have to know what phase you're in and what's important at that phase.
quotes.speaker: Tamar Yehoshua
quotes.context: A phase-based operating model: what “good” looks like changes as the company scales, so leadership and process should match the current stage.

quotes.topic_title: Hypergrowth chaos: why it happens and limits
quotes.text: If you're changing your strategy all the time and you're changing your direction and you're changing projects on people all the time so that they can't actually achieve anything ...
quotes.speaker: Tamar Yehoshua
quotes.context: A practical boundary for “acceptable chaos”: frequent strategic thrash that prevents execution is harmful, not just messy.

quotes.topic_title: Hypergrowth chaos: why it happens and limits
quotes.text: You've got at any given point 50% of the company has been there less than six months.
quotes.speaker: Tamar Yehoshua
quotes.context: A concrete hypergrowth dynamic explaining why communication and execution break down when hiring ramps aggressively.

quotes.topic_title: Hypergrowth chaos: why it happens and limits
quotes.text: But you have to grow really fast because once you hit product market fit, if you don't, then your growth will stop.
quotes.speaker: Tamar Yehoshua
quotes.context: Counterintuitive pressure of PMF: it forces speed, which creates operational strain, but slowing down can stall momentum.

quotes.topic_title: Hypergrowth chaos: why it happens and limits
quotes.text: And look at companies like MySpace, well, they died because their product got too slow.
quotes.speaker: Tamar Yehoshua
quotes.context: A cautionary example that scaling failures (e.g., performance) can erase early product-market fit advantages.

quotes.topic_title: You don’t need a career plan: follow people
quotes.text: So what I believe, and I've always believed is that you follow people. You learn the most from people.
quotes.speaker: Tamar Yehoshua
quotes.context: A simple career-navigation heuristic: optimize for learning by choosing who you work with, not a rigid long-term plan.

quotes.topic_title: You don’t need a career plan: follow people
quotes.text: But you follow people who are the best at what they do. So it's not good enough to follow somebody who you like. You want to follow somebody who's either the best product thinker or the best engineer or the best salesperson.
quotes.speaker: Tamar Yehoshua
quotes.context: Raises the bar from “people you like” to “people who will compound your skills,” making the advice highly actionable.

quotes.topic_title: You don’t need a career plan: follow people
quotes.text: So you follow people where you're going to learn the most. And a way to do that also is you look at where the great people are going.
quotes.speaker: Tamar Yehoshua
quotes.context: A practical method for identifying high-growth environments: track talent flows to find learning-dense companies and teams.

quotes.topic_title: You don’t need a career plan: follow people
quotes.text: She said to me, "Take a job where if you hire people, it's going to make their careers."
quotes.speaker: Tamar Yehoshua
quotes.context: A memorable leadership filter for job selection that prioritizes building a place worth recruiting into.

quotes.topic_title: You don’t need a career plan: follow people
quotes.text: And I've found that financial returns are the hardest to predict. You know who's good. You know who you want to work with. You can predict where you're going to learn.
quotes.speaker: Tamar Yehoshua
quotes.context: Counterbalances compensation-driven decisions with a more controllable metric—learning and talent quality.

quotes.topic_title: Choosing roles: recruitability and avoiding mercenary traps
quotes.text: some people are putting too much emphasis on where will I get a big financial return? And I've found that financial returns are the hardest to predict.
quotes.speaker: Tamar Yehoshua
quotes.context: Challenges the common job-selection heuristic of optimizing for upside by emphasizing how unpredictable financial outcomes are.

quotes.topic_title: Choosing roles: recruitability and avoiding mercenary traps
quotes.text: You know who's good. You know who you want to work with. You can predict where you're going to learn. Because even if a company fails, you learn a lot.
quotes.speaker: Tamar Yehoshua
quotes.context: Offers a practical decision framework: prioritize known quantities (people and learning) over uncertain outcomes (company success).

quotes.topic_title: Choosing roles: recruitability and avoiding mercenary traps
quotes.text: I had one person say, "I took this job because I'm a mercenary. They just paid me a ton." Did not work out for him.
quotes.speaker: Tamar Yehoshua
quotes.context: A cautionary example illustrating the risk of choosing roles primarily for compensation.

quotes.topic_title: Choosing roles: recruitability and avoiding mercenary traps
quotes.text: There's lots of good companies and there's lots of smart people. You don't have to be at the top brand.
quotes.speaker: Tamar Yehoshua
quotes.context: Reframes career progression away from prestige-chasing toward finding strong teams and growth opportunities anywhere.

quotes.topic_title: Choosing roles: recruitability and avoiding mercenary traps
quotes.text: Skills can't be taken away. A company can fail, but if you learn a skill, you will always have that skill.
quotes.speaker: Tamar Yehoshua
quotes.context: A memorable mental model for de-risking career moves by treating skill acquisition as the durable return.

quotes.topic_title: Lessons from Jeff Bezos: principles and long-termism
quotes.text: You write a six pager about ... It's like studying for the final exam is writing these six pagers.
quotes.speaker: Tamar Yehoshua
quotes.context: A concrete methodology for forcing clarity and rigor before meetings instead of relying on slides.

quotes.topic_title: Lessons from Jeff Bezos: principles and long-termism
quotes.text: First he does not speak until everybody around the table speaks.
quotes.speaker: Tamar Yehoshua
quotes.context: A repeatable leadership tactic that prevents anchoring and surfaces independent thinking from the team.

quotes.topic_title: Lessons from Jeff Bezos: principles and long-termism
quotes.text: For me, the biggest takeaway from those meetings was his consistency, which is he had principles that it made it easier for you to operate in his company because you knew what he cared about because he always had these principles.
quotes.speaker: Tamar Yehoshua
quotes.context: Highlights how consistent principles act as an operating system for scaling decision-making across a large org.

quotes.topic_title: Lessons from Jeff Bezos: principles and long-termism
quotes.text: And he looks at me and he said, "That is your advantage."
quotes.speaker: Tamar Yehoshua
quotes.context: A counterintuitive reframing: being out-resourced can be a strategic advantage rather than a handicap.

quotes.topic_title: Lessons from Jeff Bezos: principles and long-termism
quotes.text: You can't look at it in the near term. You have to be in it for the long term.
quotes.speaker: Tamar Yehoshua
quotes.context: A practical long-termism reminder for product strategy and resourcing decisions when building over years.

quotes.topic_title: Lessons from Stewart Butterfield: vision and prototyping
quotes.text: So in 2014, he wrote a master plan for Slack, which was build a product people love, build a network. That's Slack Connect. Build a platform that makes all of your other SaaS products more valuable. That's Slack Platform. And then do some magic AI stuff.
quotes.speaker: Tamar Yehoshua
quotes.context: A clear, reusable product strategy framework: loveable core product + network + platform + AI as a long-term pillar.

quotes.topic_title: Lessons from Stewart Butterfield: vision and prototyping
quotes.text: There was a grid with four boxes in 2014 and it never changed.
quotes.speaker: Tamar Yehoshua
quotes.context: Highlights the power of a stable, simple long-term strategy that guides shifting yearly execution.

quotes.topic_title: Lessons from Stewart Butterfield: vision and prototyping
quotes.text: And I think the thing that I learned from him the most was the power of prototyping.
quotes.speaker: Tamar Yehoshua
quotes.context: Emphasizes prototyping as a core leadership tool for making better product decisions, not just a design step.

quotes.topic_title: Lessons from Stewart Butterfield: vision and prototyping
quotes.text: I can't tell you if this is going to work. I have to feel it. I have to try it. And a mock-up doesn't tell you what it's going to feel like.
quotes.speaker: Tamar Yehoshua
quotes.context: A practical methodology: validate product changes through interactive prototypes because static mocks miss experiential issues.

quotes.topic_title: Lessons from Stewart Butterfield: vision and prototyping
quotes.text: And Stewart came in and said, "I want you to take everything in the interface and put it behind one button."
quotes.speaker: Tamar Yehoshua
quotes.context: A counterintuitive prototyping exercise that forces teams to rethink what truly deserves space in the UI and information architecture.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: The most successful people that I know surround themselves with incredible peers.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Highlights a practical career-growth lever: intentionally building a high-quality peer network.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: When you have a trusted group of peers, you can discuss challenges you're having, get career advice and just gut check how you're thinking about your work, your career and your life.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Defines the concrete functions a peer group can serve for better decision-making and career navigation.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: This gives you more than a leg up. It gives you a leap forward.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A memorable framing of the compounding impact of strong peer support versus incremental self-improvement.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: 93% of members say Sidebar helped them achieve a significant positive change in their career.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Provides a specific outcome metric to evaluate the program’s claimed impact.

quotes.topic_title: Making time for prototypes: mindset and tech stack
quotes.text: If you're doing it right, it'll be faster and you need to have an engineering infrastructure that enables prototyping.
quotes.speaker: Tamar Yehoshua
quotes.context: Reframes prototyping as a speed advantage when the underlying engineering system is designed to support it.

quotes.topic_title: Making time for prototypes: mindset and tech stack
quotes.text: But you have to have a layer of abstraction that enables you to do that, and you have to have engineers who have a prototyping mindset, and if you build multiple things and you have this mindset as I'm willing to throw it away, you write code that is never going to make it to production so you can just crank it out much faster and then you can see what works and then you build the production code.
quotes.speaker: Tamar Yehoshua
quotes.context: Offers a concrete methodology for faster prototyping: abstraction + “throwaway code” mindset + iterate before productionizing.

quotes.topic_title: Making time for prototypes: mindset and tech stack
quotes.text: We had a problem with our mobile apps that it was too hard to prototype and we actually redesigned our mobile apps until we got to the point where it was easier because our desktop app was pretty easy to prototype.
quotes.speaker: Tamar Yehoshua
quotes.context: A specific example of changing the product/architecture itself to make prototyping easier and faster.

quotes.topic_title: Making time for prototypes: mindset and tech stack
quotes.text: When I was at Google, one of our teams, a front-end team, I remember we hired a bunch of prototypers and our head of front-end engineering said to me one day, this is my secret weapon. This is how we move faster.
quotes.speaker: Tamar Yehoshua
quotes.context: Highlights a team-structure tactic—dedicated prototypers—as a lever for speed.

quotes.topic_title: Making time for prototypes: mindset and tech stack
quotes.text: There's this video recently that went around on Twitter where an eight-year-old girl was building an app and in like 45 minutes, she built a chatbot using this product called Cursor.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A vivid data point illustrating how AI tools are compressing prototyping time dramatically.

quotes.topic_title: Other leadership lessons: Benioff’s marketing as product
quotes.text: I think that there are people who are really, really good at what they do. So Marc Benioff is an amazing marketeer. His marketing mind ...
quotes.speaker: Tamar Yehoshua
quotes.context: Highlights the practitioner lesson that marketing can be a core, differentiating competency worth studying as deeply as product or engineering.

quotes.topic_title: Other leadership lessons: Benioff’s marketing as product
quotes.text: Dreamforce is incredible at the impact that it has on the ecosystem.
quotes.speaker: Tamar Yehoshua
quotes.context: Points to a scalable strategy: treat major events as ecosystem-building levers, not just brand moments.

quotes.topic_title: Other leadership lessons: Benioff’s marketing as product
quotes.text: Well, they went into their competitor's conference and stood outside their competitor's conference.
quotes.speaker: Tamar Yehoshua
quotes.context: A concrete example of bold competitive positioning—creating attention by showing up where your competitor owns mindshare.

quotes.topic_title: Other leadership lessons: Benioff’s marketing as product
quotes.text: And it takes his guts. He pushes the envelope.
quotes.speaker: Tamar Yehoshua
quotes.context: Underscores that standout marketing often requires calculated risk-taking rather than safe, conventional tactics.

quotes.topic_title: Other leadership lessons: Benioff’s marketing as product
quotes.text: He approaches his marketing presentations like a product person approaches their building their product.
quotes.speaker: Tamar Yehoshua
quotes.context: A transferable mental model: design marketing (especially keynotes) with product-thinking—intentional UX, narrative, and iteration.

quotes.topic_title: Building strong PM–engineering partnerships and alignment
quotes.text: Probably the most important thing that a product leader does because if you have great ideas of what to build, but you can't get them built, then you go nowhere.
quotes.speaker: Tamar Yehoshua
quotes.context: Frames PM–engineering partnership as a core execution lever: ideas are worthless without delivery.

quotes.topic_title: Building strong PM–engineering partnerships and alignment
quotes.text: So one, make sure somewhere where you have a good engineering partner.
quotes.speaker: Tamar Yehoshua
quotes.context: Actionable hiring/role-selection criterion: evaluate the engineering counterpart as part of deciding whether you can succeed.

quotes.topic_title: Building strong PM–engineering partnerships and alignment
quotes.text: You don't want any of this ... People in the organization, they asked Mom, they asked dad and they got different opinions and playing one against the other, that doesn't work.
quotes.speaker: Tamar Yehoshua
quotes.context: Memorable mental model for avoiding misalignment and organizational “triangulation” between product and engineering leaders.

quotes.topic_title: Building strong PM–engineering partnerships and alignment
quotes.text: And we would say, "Okay. Who's going to take this one?" And we would do all our reviews together.
quotes.speaker: Tamar Yehoshua
quotes.context: Concrete operating mechanism: explicitly assign ownership while maintaining joint visibility through shared reviews.

quotes.topic_title: Building strong PM–engineering partnerships and alignment
quotes.text: And then Cal and I would do a marathon and we would watch them all together.
quotes.speaker: Tamar Yehoshua
quotes.context: Specific example of an alignment ritual: synchronous “marathon” review of async team OKR videos to stay calibrated.

quotes.topic_title: Don’t over-index on unhappy users during changes
quotes.text: So design it for the bigger number of people who are going to be using it tomorrow.
quotes.speaker: Tamar Yehoshua
quotes.context: A future-oriented product principle: optimize for tomorrow’s scaled user base rather than today’s vocal minority.

quotes.topic_title: Don’t over-index on unhappy users during changes
quotes.text: So a product manager gets caught in this trap of the vocal minority and the number of people using your product ... Depends on what phase. Are you a Google? Are you Slack? Are you a Glean? But the number of people using your product today is usually unless you're a Google far smaller than the number of people who are going to be using your product tomorrow.
quotes.speaker: Tamar Yehoshua
quotes.context: A scaling mental model that reframes feedback: current users are not representative of future users, especially pre-scale.

quotes.topic_title: Don’t over-index on unhappy users during changes
quotes.text: If you have to redo the UI and the Who Moved My Cheese, people will be unhappy, but all the new people are going to be like, "This is so much easier." Then do it and deal with the people who are unhappy.
quotes.speaker: Tamar Yehoshua
quotes.context: A pragmatic change-management stance: accept short-term dissatisfaction to unlock long-term usability for new users.

quotes.topic_title: Don’t over-index on unhappy users during changes
quotes.text: But the trick is you have to be respectful and you have to be transparent and you have to explain.
quotes.speaker: Tamar Yehoshua
quotes.context: A simple execution rule for making breaking changes without eroding trust.

quotes.topic_title: Don’t over-index on unhappy users during changes
quotes.text: You can't be dismissive and you can't have marketing speak. You have to really say, "Here's for real why."
quotes.speaker: Tamar Yehoshua
quotes.context: A communication standard for product changes: authenticity beats polished messaging when users are impacted.
